text: from Yuri Gagarin the first man in space
to that famous step taken by Neil
Armstrong to our own Tim Peake mankind
has shown an unquenchable desire to
explore outer space
practice makes perfect this man reached
for the stars governments had to decide
what law would govern space exploration
we shall send them all a giant rocket
forged in the Cold War where both
superpowers fear the other would
colonize space and install nuclear
weapons on the moon the outer space
treaty was signed in 1967 meanwhile the
Foreign Minister presided at the signing
of the treaty banning nuclear weapons
from outer space he created the founding
legal framework for space law critically
banning all signatory nations from
installing weapons of mass destruction
in outer space or on planets or
asteroids about such a treaty life on
earth would be under continual threat
that nightmare existence and prohibiting
any government from claiming ownership
of a planet or celestial resource
claiming that they're the common
heritage of mankind
fueled in part by billionaires the
promise of rich untapped resources and
the sheer thrill of life beyond planet
Earth the commercial possibilities of
space are being explored like never
before
the law governing human activity in
space may have its origins in the 1950s
and 60s but such has been the dramatic
expansion in space exploration in recent
decades but many now believe there needs
to be a second generation of binding
international law firstly what we don't
want is for space to become an area of
conflict and dispute international
agreement is the best way to ensure that
space activity proceeds in an orderly
fashion but I think secondly and perhaps
most importantly of all is an issue of
sustainability what we don't want is to
corrupt pristine environments how great
space is getting crowded there are more
than half a million pieces of debris or
space junk bits of old rockets and
satellites orbiting the Earth at 28,000
kilometers per hour and in November
President Obama signed into law the
commercial space act giving US citizens
the right to exploit minerals which some
believe may violate the outer space
treaties ban on the ownership of
celestial bodies I think it's important
for people to be able to get their
financial return if they make an
investment but it's got to be under some
form of license even in the Wild West as
people physically stake their claims to
to to ground they were doing it under
some form of license and at the moment
we don't have a license body
as far as we know tim peake won't be
consulting a lawyer whilst in space but
as mankind continues its quest to the
final frontier the law governing human
behavior in space will come under
increasing scrutiny
Clark Coleman BBC News
